cookingTips.title: Keep Your Knives Sharp
cookingTips.tip: A sharp knife is safer and more efficient than a dull one. It requires less pressure and gives you better control.

cookingTips.title: Season Throughout Cooking
cookingTips.tip: Don't just season at the end. Add salt and spices at different stages to build layers of flavor.

cookingTips.title: Let Meat Rest
cookingTips.tip: After cooking meat, let it rest for 5-10 minutes. This allows juices to redistribute, making it more tender.

cookingTips.title: Mise en Place
cookingTips.tip: Prepare all ingredients before you start cooking. Having everything measured and chopped saves time and reduces stress.

cookingTips.title: Room Temperature Ingredients
cookingTips.tip: Bring ingredients like eggs, butter, and dairy to room temperature before baking for better mixing and texture.

cookingTips.title: Don't Overcrowd the Pan
cookingTips.tip: When searing or saut√©ing, give ingredients space. Overcrowding steams food instead of browning it.

cookingTips.title: Taste as You Go
cookingTips.tip: Continuously taste your food while cooking. This helps you adjust seasoning and catch problems early.

cookingTips.title: Control Your Heat
cookingTips.tip: Most home cooks use too high heat. Lower, controlled heat often produces better results.

cookingTips.title: Keep It Clean
cookingTips.tip: Clean as you go to maintain food safety and make cleanup easier. Wash hands frequently.

cookingTips.title: Quality Ingredients Matter
cookingTips.tip: Use the best ingredients you can afford. Fresh, quality ingredients make a noticeable difference in taste.
